unnormalised: My earliest memory of understanding the weight of a title comes from my grandmother, Shrimati Kamala Devi. Not just Kamala, but Shrimati Kamala Devi. The ‘Shrimati’ always preceded her name, a marker of respect, of a woman who had borne children and managed a household with grace. It was a title not earned in a boardroom or a university, but in the quiet, everyday acts of love and sacrifice.

unnormalised: I remember being a mischievous kid, always running around and addressed by my given name, Rohan. But my grandmother was always introduced as Shrimati Kamala Devi when guests came over, a stark contrast to my grandfather, Shri. Rajesh Sharma, the ‘Shri’ sounding a little more…formal? Less intimate, maybe? At that age, the difference was just another one of those grown-up things I couldn't quite grasp.

unnormalised: As I grew older, the nuances started to become clearer. The older women in our colony, the ones who organised the Diwali pujas and the Ganesh Chaturthi celebrations, were all addressed as Smt. before their first name. It wasn't just a name; it was an acknowledgement of their role, their status, their contribution to the community. It was a title that carried weight, signifying experience and wisdom.

It wasn't just a name; it was an acknowledgement of their role, their status, their contribution to the community. It was a title that carried weight, signifying experience and wisdom.

unnormalised: Then there were the men. Shri. was ubiquitous. Shri. Kumar at the bank, Shri. Patel the shopkeeper, Shri. Verma the landlord. It felt more like a default setting, a prefix that was simply…there. No real weight attached. Unless, of course, you were addressing someone higher up the pecking order. Then it became “Shri. Honorable Chief Minister” or “Shri. Respected Director.” The additional honorifics elevated the title, amplifying the respect.

unnormalised: Later, I encountered other titles. Kumari, for the unmarried young women. It seemed a marker of potential, of innocence, perhaps a little restrictive in its implications. Then there were the professional titles: Dr. Sharma, Prof. Gupta, Adv. Iyer. Earned titles, badges of accomplishment, representing years of study and hard work. These felt very different from the social titles; they were declarations of expertise, of authority within a specific domain. Dr. Patel’s medical advice held a different kind of weight than Smt. Verma’s recipe for the perfect gulab jamun.

unnormalised: Moving to Mumbai for my MBA, I realized the title game was even more complex. In the corporate world, it was all about Mr. and Ms. Gender-neutral, efficient, and devoid of any of the cultural baggage of Shrimati or Kumari. It was about professionalism, about your role, your designation. Manager Singh, CEO Kapoor – these titles defined your position in the hierarchy, impacting everything from your salary to your seating arrangement in the office.

Manager Singh, C-E-O Kapoor – these titles defined your position in the hierarchy, impacting everything from your salary to your seating arrangement in the office.

unnormalised: Now, working as a consultant and traveling across India, I navigate a maze of titles daily. Understanding the subtle power dynamics encoded within these prefixes and suffixes feels crucial. Addressing someone correctly, showing the appropriate level of respect, can open doors and build relationships. Misstep, and you risk causing offense, jeopardizing a deal, or simply being perceived as culturally insensitive. It's a fascinating game, this dance of titles, a reflection of India's complex social fabric.

unnormalised: In the end, though, I still believe my grandmother's "Shrimati" carried the most weight. It was a title earned not through ambition or achievement, but through a lifetime of quiet strength and unwavering love. A title that whispered of home, of heritage, of the unquantifiable value of a life well-lived.
